definition: **The circulatory system** (cardiovascular system) is the organ system that <u>circulates blood throughout the body</u> via the heart and blood vessels. Its primary purpose is to <u>deliver oxygen and nutrients</u> to tissues and to carry away carbon dioxide and other waste products for elimination.
tips: Major components: the <u>heart</u> (muscular pump), <u>arteries</u> (vessels carrying blood away from the heart), <u>capillaries</u> (tiny vessels where exchange of gases/nutrients occurs), and <u>veins</u> (vessels returning blood to the heart).

Humans have a **<u>closed circulatory system</u>**, meaning blood stays within vessels. There are two circuits: the <u>pulmonary circulation</u> (heart to lungs and back, for gas exchange) and <u>systemic circulation</u> (heart to body and back).

Arteries generally carry oxygenated blood and veins carry deoxygenated blood, with a notable exception: the <u>pulmonary arteries</u> carry oxygen-poor blood from the heart to the lungs, and <u>pulmonary veins</u> carry oxygen-rich blood back to the heart.
exam_appearance: Look for clues about oxygen delivery or waste removal. For example: "Which system transports oxygen to cells and removes carbon dioxide?" - the <u>circulatory system</u>.

Common trap: assuming all arteries carry oxygenated blood. A classic question might ask which artery carries deoxygenated blood - the correct answer is the <u>pulmonary artery</u> (since it goes to the lungs to pick up oxygen).
